verses.verse: When they got close to Jerusalem and arrived at Bethphage next to the Mount of Olives, Jesus sent two disciples, Mat 21:2 telling them, "Go into the village in front of you, and immediately you will find a donkey tied and a colt with her. Loose them and bring them to me.
"If anyone says anything to you, you tell them, «The Lord has need of them,' and immediately he will send them."
All this was done so that it might be fulfilled what was spoken by the prophet saying,
"You tell the daughter of Zion, «Look! Your king comes to you, meek, and riding on a donkey and on a colt the foal of a donkey.'"
So the disciples went and did as Jesus commanded them.
They brought the donkey and colt and put their cloaks on them, then they set [him] on them.
A very large crowd spread their cloaks on the road; others cut down branches from the trees and spread them on the road.
The crowd that went in front and those who followed shouted saying, "Hosanna to the Son of David. Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord. Hosanna in the highest."
When he had come into Jerusalem, the whole city was stirred up saying, "Who is this?"
The crowd said, "This is Jesus, the prophet of Nazareth of Galilee."
Jesus went into the Temple of God and threw out all those who sold and bought in the temple. He also overturned the table of the money changers and the seats of those who sold doves.
He said to them, "It is written, «My house will be called the House of Prayer, but you have made it a den of thieves.»
The blind and the lame came to him in the temple, and he healed them.
When the chief priests and scribes saw the wonderful things that he did and the children shouting in the temple saying, "Hosanna to the Son of David," they were outraged.
They said to him, "Don't you hear what they say?" Jesus said to them, "Yes, have you never read, «Out of the mouth of little children and nursing children you have perfected praise.»
Then he left them and went out of the city to Bethany and stayed there.
Now in the morning as he returned into the city, he was hungry.
When he saw a fig tree on the way, he came to it and found nothing except leaves and said to it, "Let no fruit grow on you from now to eternity." Instantly the fig tree withered.
When the disciples saw [it], they marveled saying, "How quickly the fig tree withered!"

Jesus answered and said to them, "Truly I say to you: If you have faith and don't doubt, you will not only do this to the fig tree, but if you also will say to this mountain: Be removed; be thrown into the sea. It will be done.
"All things whatever you will ask in prayer, believing, you will receive."
When he had come to the temple, the chief priests and elders of the people came to him as he was teaching and said, "By what authority do you do these things? And who gave you this authority?"
Jesus answered and said to them, "I will also ask you one thing, which if you tell me, I likewise will tell you by what authority I do these things.
"John's baptism, where did it come from--heaven or men?" They talked it over, "If we will say, «From heaven,» he will say to us, "Why didn't you believe him then?
"But if we will say, «From men.» We fear the people, for all hold John as a prophet."
Then they answered Jesus and said, "We don't know." So he said to them, "Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things.
"Now what do you think? A certain man had two sons. He came to the first and said, «Son, go work in my vineyard today.»
"He answered and said, «I will not,» but afterward he repented and went.
"Then he came to the second and said the same. He answered and said, «I go sir,» but he didn't go.

"Which of the two then did the father's will?" They said to him, "The first." Jesus said to them, "Truly, I say to you, «That the tax collectors and harlots will go into the Kingdom of God before you.»

"For John came to you in the path of righteousness, but you didn't believe him. But the tax collectors and harlots believed him. And when you saw it, you didn't repent afterward, so that you might believe him.

"Hear another parable: There was a certain landowner, who planted a vineyard and hedged it all around. He also dug a winepress on it and built a tower. He then leased it to tenants and went into a far off country.
"When the harvest time drew near, he sent his servants to the tenants, so that to receive its harvest.
"The tenants took his servant and beat one, killed another, and stoned another.
"Again he sent other servants, even more than the first, and they did the same thing to them.
"But finally he sent his son to them, saying, «They will reverence my son.»
"But when the tenants saw the son, they said among themselves, «This is the heir; come, let us kill him and seize his inheritance.»
"They seized him, threw him out of the vineyard, and murdered him.
"When the lord of the vineyard therefore came, what will he do to those tenants?"
They said to him, "He will miserably destroy those wicked men and will lease the vineyard to other tenants who will deliver the harvests on time to him."
Jesus said to them, "Have you never read in the Scriptures, «The stone which the builders rejected, the same has become the head of the corner. This is marvelous in our eyes.»
"Therefore I say to you, «The Kingdom of God will be taken from you and given to a nation bringing forth the harvest of it.
"And whosoever will fall on this stone will be broken, but on whomever it will fall, it will grind him to powder.»
When the chief priests and Pharisees had heard his parables, they perceived that he spoke about them.
But when they tried to lay hands on him, they feared the crowd, because they held him as a prophet.
